hobby.message: Political literature still your guilty pleasure?
Urban exploration ever get boring for you?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I collect political literature. It's a reminder of what was lost.
neutral_answer: Weather’s the least of anyone’s troubles tonight.
I keep myself occupied collecting old pamphlets and books. Nothing illegal, only history.
The recent outages made it harder to find anything worth saving.
City’s as dry as the channels. Feels tighter each night.
I collect banned political pamphlets, mostly for the history.
Swapping anything these days is slow—power cuts and scanners everywhere.
Had to postpone a trade. Not worth the risk lately.
Dry, yes, but dark too. That Harmony Reset did a number on my routine.
I’m a collector. Banned political literature, samizdat, objections in ink—my idea of a pastime.
Tried to swap a rare pamphlet last week after curfew. Nearly missed my contact thanks to the blackouts.
Funny how outages make even collecting feel subversive.
Some pieces are riskier to move than others. I keep backups, in code.
Still dry, unless you count the arid space between checkpoints.
I collect early protest memorabilia—pamphlets, forbidden essays, the rarer the better.
Each trade’s a little ritual. Timing and caution take half the fun these days.
Last run, I got a samizdat copy of ‘On Dissent.’ Nearly canceled after BCI flared up.
Checkpoint guards barely cared last time, but any mistake risks a flag.
Since the Harmony Reset, it’s underground or nothing. Half the city’s collectors are in limbo.
Most of what I keep, I can quote by heart. I like to rescue lost voices.
Still dry outside, Alex. Inside, history’s soaked with erasure and fear.
I’m obsessed with banned literature—pamphlets, manifestos from before BCI neutered dissent.
Half my evenings go to finding, coding, trading them. Keeps my mind alive.
Just last week, a blackout nearly stranded me with a first printing of ‘Manifesto for Remembrance.’
BCI resets jolted every handoff—one wrong blip, and you’re flagged for ‘noncompliance.’
Some days, it’s about saving words from disappearance. Others, it’s knowing you’re not alone in this city.
I’ve stashed encoded copies everywhere. If they vanish me, at least the ideas persist.
Funny thing, Alex. I write the Council’s speeches, but in secret, I quote the banned ones.
hobby_answer: Yes, still keeps me up. Harder now with these blackout routines.
Harmony Reset's made trading almost impossible. Streets are watched.
Rare prints stay hidden. Not worth the risk with patrols about.
Power outages mean reading's done by candlelight, if at all.
Safer to leave shelves untouched these days.
Yes, political literature. Still my escape, if you can call it that.
Reset’s made exchanges difficult. Everyone’s watching everyone.
Met a friend last week, barely made it past two checkpoints.
A pamphlet almost cost me my BCI score—close call.
Honestly, most of what I read now stays in coded notes.
Feels like the old days, just quieter.
It does. The texts never sleep—nor do I, lately.
Trading’s a maze now. Harmony Reset closed old routes.
Last swap nearly got me flagged: too many patrols, too few shadows.
I keep the rare pieces locked away. Only the battered ones ever leave home.
Sometimes I copy passages by hand to pass the time in blackout hours.
Funny, the less light we have, the sharper the words seem.
Recent crackdowns just make every page feel more urgent.
Absolutely. Banned pamphlets, lost manifestos—they're my real currency.
Harmony Reset forced all the best collectors underground. Signals flicker, eyes everywhere.
Last week’s trade—old edition for pre-BCI memoir—felt like crossing enemy lines.
Checkpoint scanners glitched. Nearly cost me two points on my score.
Spent an hour waiting in a dark alley, trading lines from memory.
I read by lamplight, copy notes in cipher. It's ritual, not just risk.
We've all learned to value fragments. Whole volumes are nearly impossible now.
Honestly, the danger's sharpened my taste for the text itself.
Always. The shelves are my confession. Political texts, banned verses—every era's shadow lives there.
First editions from the reform years, carbon copies passed hand to hand.
Last week, traded with a contact stranded by Harmony Reset. He walked four districts—risked patrols, score loss.
We exchanged in complete silence. Not a word. Code and memory only.
BCI down meant no vetting, just trust—rare these days, even among collectors.
I scribbled a passage from memory in my notebook under candlelight, just for insurance.
The pamphlet changed hands. Felt like preserving a ghost, honestly.
Reset's power cuts make reading feel illicit again—like propaganda’s inverse, in the bones.
Most nights, I wonder if we'll look back on these blackout hours as our real archives.
